Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:The Study of Novel Liquid Crystal Structures for use in Organic Solar Cell Technologies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Solar cells represent a promising technology to replace fossil fuels due to the abundance of energy the sun provides to the Earth?s surface every day. Industrial solar cells currently use inorganic materials which have some advantages over organic materials; primarily the former are more efficient than the latter. However, inorganic materials are also expensive, inflexible and bulky, and are restricted to relatively small area devices. Novel organic materials can be used to overcome the cost and manufacturing limitations of current solar cell technologies. One unique organic material?a liquid crystal structure called a helical nanofilament?will be studied for its potential effectiveness in solar cell devices. This work will be conducted at KAIST in Korea with Professor Dong Ki Yoon, a world-leading expert in liquid crystal alignment techniques.

Liquid crystals have been observed to have excellent organic semiconducting properties, making them a good candidate for use in organic photovoltaics. Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that bent core liquid crystals that form ?nanowire-like? helical nanofilaments can be aligned using various techniques including convection cooling, substrate surface energy modification, and nano-confinement. This offers the ability to align these filaments, and composites containing a second ?guest? material, within photovoltaic devices with relative ease, potentially leading to more efficient exciton splitting and charge transport within devices. A first look at helical nanofilaments for use in photovoltaics will be studied by placing them within an organic field effect transistor device to extract charge carrier mobility in orthogonal directions, giving insight to the efficacy of aligned helical nanofilaments in photovoltaic devices.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Helical Nanofilaments (HNFs) are long rods made of twisted layers composed of organic, bent-core liquid crystal (BCLCs) molecules that can be described as nanowires. These nanowires are proposed to be excellent charge transporters. However, up to this point, the ability to measure this transport has been hindered by the lack of alignment in HNFs. In general, poorly aligned organic materials transport charge inefficiently, thus it is important to explore robust and easily reproducible material alignment techniques to improve the charge transport and ultimately the performance of organic materials. In this study, we explored the use of the template assisted self-assembly method to align HNFs resulting in freestanding microchannels of HNFs for use in organic electronic devices. 

An elastomer was placed over a silicon substrate etched with grooves that were one centimeter long and micrometers in height and width. The mold was then cured and cut out to be placed on a glass microscope slide. HNF forming material was filled into the channels above their melting point and cooled to room temperature. When the mold was removed, freestanding microchannels of HNFs remained. After analysis of the microchannels using various techniques including polarized light microcscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and x-ray diffraction, it was concluded that the microchannels were well aligned throughout. 

The study continued by exploring the alignment of BCLCs that exhibit various liquid crystal phases. These materials were also placed into the microchannel mold and a high degree of alignment was achieved. The ubiquitous alignment of many materials using this method demonstrates the propensity for universal and consistent alignment of all BCLCs within the channels. This indicates that the material plays a role in the alignment of HNFs and other materials within the channels. 

This technique, which has been used to align materials for organic electronics, has been shown to also align BCLCs and specifically HNFs. The reproducible alignment of HNFs has never been seen before in freestanding channels or over such a long range. The alignment of exotic liquid crystal phases could lead to new studies not previously possibly in unaligned samples. Also, this could prove useful for use in new, improved organic electronics with well-aligned materials, revolutionizing our use of electronics in society.
